person.note: In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read ̓Αβιδων. In Hebrew it would read אבידון. On the additional ו in the suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.1, p. 13.
In Coptic – ⲡⲁⲣⲭⲏⲉⲣⲉⲩⲥ. On this title see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4.
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
On the interchange of the letters י and ו see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.1, p. 13.
See next note.
Aaron is described as דמן אבודן (of Abudan) but no such place is recorded. Thus it may be a family name, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.2, p. 46.
Suggested by CIIP1/2 no. 881.
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read אביה.
On the Samaritan sects see Introduction 3.3.3. According to Abu’l Fath, the sect of this Abiah and Dositheus (1) is to be understood separately from the great Samaritan Dosithean heresy.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.2. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
On Abu’l Fath’s dating of Samaritan sects, see Introduction 7.2.2.1.
Was a student of Rabbi Jonathan (1), who was also a teacher of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

On the form ̓Αβιάθαρsee vol. 3, under Ebiathar (1) B/M, p. 1. On the interchange of θ and τ see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.6, p. 21. The fall of the α is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20.
Jewishness indicated both by his name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 60-1, and perhaps also because it is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, 35.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.
On this form see vol. 3, Abraham (13) B/M, p. 72.

The story of this person’s conversion to Judaism begins with the words: ἐγένετό τις παράδειγμα μοναχός (there was a certain exemplary monk). If this is the name he adopted after he converted, this is the first instance of the name Abraham serving for converts. Later on it became the standard name for male proselytes, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
See previous note and vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.3, p. 50.
See H. Sivan, Palestine in Late Antiquity (Oxford 2008) 51.
For this form see under Abraham (9) B/M, vol. 3, p. 73, n. 23.
On the dating of this text see Dan, Zion 36 (1971).
שמטעימה, which is probably a nickname.
Appears in a list of leaders who were accorded territory by the Samaritan leader Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 3.3.1.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He was his contemporary.
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late, but see Introduction 6.4.1.
See Introduction 7.6.6 and previous note.

For this form as being an abbreviation of the biblical name Abraham, in which the Hebrew suffix fell because it was interpreted as belonging to a misunderstood case system, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12.
In Latin – Sir[..], see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Near Venice , in Italy.
The name and provenance made editors consider it Jewish, but the name was also common among Syrian Christians, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.ref: See above, n. 14. For this form as being an abbreviation of the biblical name Abraham, in which the Hebrew suffix fell because it was interpreted as belonging to a misunderstood case system, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12.

person.note: This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
In vol. 3 both the form ̓Αβραμος (see under Abraham [2] B/M, p. 72) and ̓Αβρααμίος(see under Abraham [9] B/M, p. 72) are recorded. This is a combination of the two.

note.ref: See above, n. 14. For this form as being an abbreviation of the biblical name Abraham, in which the Hebrew suffix fell because it was interpreted as belonging to a misunderstood case system, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12.

person.note: The inscription comes from the antiquities market. The man who traded this inscription claimed that it comes from a place associated with Abraham. Mordtmann understood this to refer to Hebron.

This inscription was presumably found in Hebron. It mentions the biblical Abraham, Isaac and Aaron. It could be Jewish but is could of course just as likely be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
His daughter is mentioned in association with Eleazar (8), see Introduction 7.4.3.

So in the printed version to bBB 68a, This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 1, under Eutolmus (3) G/M, p. 279. Perhaps this was his name, and אבשלום is a scribal “correction” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.
So in the Vatican 115 Ms to bBB 68a, see previous note. On the form אבטולמוס see previous note. On the fall of the וs see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.4, p. 13.

So in the Florence II-I-9 Ms to bBB 68a, see above, n. 3. So in the printed version to bBB 68a, This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 1, under Eutolmus (3) G/M, p. 279. Perhaps this was his name, and אבשלום is a scribal “correction” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. For this form see vol. 1, under Eutolmus (2) G/M, p. 279.

So in the printed versions of bBer 7b, see above, n. 3. So in the printed version to bBB 68a, This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 1, under Eutolmus (3) G/M, p. 279. Perhaps this was his name, and אבשלום is a scribal “correction” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. For this form see vol. 1, under Abshalom (6) B/M, p. 60.

Although mentioned only in BT, his son is designated רבי in all the traditions in which he is mentioned (bBer7a; bMeg14a and bBB 68a), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2 and transmits traditions in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5.
Mentioned in no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
In Thamoudian script, see Introduction 2.5.3. On biblical names losing their vocalization see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13.
A village in Transjordan, near Karak.
Jewishness sugested based on name, see vol. 3, Intruduction 6.6, pp. 50-1. However the region is not particularly Jewish and the inscription is in the Thamoudean script, see Intruduction 2.2.1.6.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

Althouth this form is not recorded elsewhere, it seems like a standard transliteration of this name into Greek. In vol. 1, under Abshalom (3) the form ̓Αβεσσαλώμindicates the use of the letter β for this transliteration and the form σελαμ for שלום is found in the standard transliteration of the name שלמציון into Greek (e.g. in vol. 1, under Shalmzion [16] S-H/F, p. 427). The suffix is standard Greek, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1.1, p. 18.
In Greek – οἰκοδόμος. Because the inscription was found in the theatre of Beth She’an he may be the architect of the theatre. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3.
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 51. The region was not particularly Jewish in character, see Introduction 6.2.1.4.
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1.
In Aramaic – כהנה. On such titles see Introduction 3.3.2.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
These are the date of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He is his contemporary.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1.
See above, n. 3. In Aramaic – כהנה. On such titles see Introduction 3.3.2.
See above, n. 4. This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.

person.note: See above, n. 5

The inscription comes from the antiquities market. The man who produced this inscription claimed that it comes from a place associated with Abraham. Mordtmann understood this to refer to Hebron.

This inscription was presumably found in Hebron. It mentions the biblical Abraham, Isaac and Aaron. It could be Jewish but is could of course just as likely be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The replacement of א with ע and of ה with א indicate the decline of the laryngeals, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.1, pp. 28-9 and vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.1, pp. 10.
The inscription is dated to 509 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.
Was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

So in BT. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 4, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 56.
So in yErub6:7, 23d, and see previous note. For this form see vol. 4, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 56.

So in yBer 1:6, 3d, see above, n. 4. So in BT. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 4, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 56. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. This is probably a variation of the biblical name אחיה, see below. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26.
Was associated with Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a student and contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: This is his only appearance in rabbinic literature. He is the son of Abba (70) S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311, but he was probably Palestinian, as his title רבי suggests. It is well known that his father spent many years in Palestine. He is not to be identified with Ahi (23) son of Abba (60) B/M (see vol. 4, p. 56),
His father was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]) see Introduction 7.4.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: Transmits a tradition in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: His son transmits a tradition in the name of Resh Laqish (Simon [2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: In Hebrew – שר הבירה. On a possible interpretation of this name see Introduction 3.1.3.3.1.

Although he appears only in BT he bears the title רבי (see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2) and is always mentioned in association with a place in Palestine (Usha – bKet22a; bBB 146a) or Syria (Antioch – bYev45a; bKet 88a; bArakh 22b).
Was a contemporary of Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: So in the Munich 95 Ms. On such a suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.5.1. It could, however, be referring to the word “his brother” rather than to a name, see above, n. 1. Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:21. The word אחא means brother in Aramaic.
Although he shows up only in BT, he is said to appear on a divorce bill from “there” (התם), which in BT always means Palestine. He is mistakenly listed in vol. 4, under Ahi (22) B/M, p. 56.
Mentioned in a divorce bill discussed by Rav Ashi (2), who died in this year, according to ShGa § 186, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.2.1, pp. 40-1.
So only in the Vilna print. Elsewhere in the mss אחי. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (2) B/M, p. 61.
In Aramaic – בריבי. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1.
Although mentioned only in BT, here, he is mentioned as a precedent in a tradition transmitted by Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: In Hyman, Toldoth, 124, under this name, the author refers the reader to a person named אבא בר עולא. But no such person is discussed in the book. He mentions him under אבא בר עילאי (pp. 53-4).
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: His son was a student of Rabbi Asi (Joseph [29]) who was a companion of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61.

person.note: Probably also mentioned in Gen Rab 94:2, where he is recorded as בר אילא (in the London MS) and בר עולה (in the Vatican MS 30) but also as בר שילא (in the Munich 97 MS).
In Hebrew – איש כפר תמרתה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 375-6. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
His father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
For the form ̓Ηλίαςsee vol. 3, under Elijah (1) B/M, p. 76.
In Greek – πατρός. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.2, p. 40.

This person has a biblical name but he could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. L. Di Segni, Dated Greek Inscriptions from Palestine from the Roman and Byzantine Periods (PhD Thesis, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 1997) 458-60 claims that the building referred to in the inscription is civil and not religious and has pagan overtones. The title “beyond reasonable doubt … was a municiple functionary who had nothing to do with with the ecclesiastical hierarchy.” Despite the date – 1st indiction – the inscription cannot be dated. It could be early, before Christianity got a firm grip on Caesarea and the man, if not Christian, could be Jewish.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
For this form see vol. 3, under Elijah (3) B/M, p. 76.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For the form ̓Ηλίαςsee vol. 3, under Elijah (1) B/M, p. 76.

person.note: See above, n. 7. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35. .
See above, n. 8. See above, n. 2. This is probably this form without the Greek suffix, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 17-8.

In this inscription he is described as one of the friends (τῶν α̓τ[ῶν]φιλῶν) of those who inscribed the text (identified by Di Segni as Armenian). Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.

note.ref: See above, n. 8. See above, n. 2.

person.note: In Greek – μ[α]ρμα(ράριος). On such title see Introduction 3.1.3.3.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.

note.ref: See above, n. 8. See above, n. 2.

person.note: Jewishness suggested by Di Segni, based on name, and other possible features, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
See below, n. 27.
In Greek – φροντίδι ̓Ελιου στατοῦ (stewardship of Elius Magistrate – Offord’s translation). On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.4.
In north Israel, on the source of the Jordan river.

The inscription is dated to the time of Diocletian. A person named Elijah under his anti-Christian rule would have been Jewish, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1. However, this was the name of an administrative official, and it may not have been a rendition of Elijah, but rather of a Greek name, see e.g. WGE. 348-9.
The stone refers to the Diocletian at the time he assumed with Maximinus the title Augustus. These are the dates when this title would have been relevant, see Introduction 7.1.

This form (with a spiritus asper) is recorded as the name of the sun-god in Greece, see WGE, 456-7, but in the Elijah’s Cave a recurrance of forms of this rare name is suggestive. It may be a variation on the name of the hero of the cave, see Appendix 4.3.3.1.
In Hebrew, in Greek letters – βηθ (בית). On this see Appendix 4.3.3.1.2.
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.
See above, n. 23, In Hebrew, in Greek letters – βηθ (בית). On this see Appendix 4.3.3.1.2. and vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.2, p. 46.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

state.note: Cyrillus (5)’s father, the greatest, decurion of the colony Ptolemais

person.note: This form is recorded as a mythical name of the founder of Helas, see WGE, 349, but in the Elijah’s Cave a recurance of forms of this rare name is suggestive. It may be a variation on the name of the hero of the cave, see Appendix 4.3.3.1.

In Greek – Μ[έγ]ιστος, δεκου[ρί]ων Κολ(ονίας) Πτο(λεμαίδος). On the titles see Introduction 3.1.3.1 and 3.1.3.4. On the regional designataion see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. And see also Appendix 4.3.3.1.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 24. For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.
See above, n. 26. On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

See above, n. 27. This form is recorded as a mythical name of the founder of Helas, see WGE, 349, but in the Elijah’s Cave a recurance of forms of this rare name is suggestive. It may be a variation on the name of the hero of the cave, see Appendix 4.3.3.1.
See above, n. 24. For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.
See above, n. 26. On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

person.note: So in the printed edition, in Vatican 60 Ms and in other mss. In the Theodor-Albeck edition אליהו עינני, but this makes no sense.
Samuel (3) transmits a tradition in his name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

Although mentioned only in BT and only here, he is described as transmitting a tradition in the name of the Holy Community in Jerusalem (קהילא קדישא דבירושלם), see S. Safrai “The Holy Congregation in Jerusalem,” Scripta Hierosolymitana23 (1972) 62-78, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1.
His son transmits a tradition in the name of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.
So in the printed version, but in the mss אלישיב. This form is probably a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.
His son comments on the words of Resh Laqish (Simon [2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.
South-west of Safed.

Ben Zvi maintained that it is not possible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60. However, see also previous note.

person.note: Described as officiating in the days when Muhammad came to power, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.3.2, p. 42.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Was associated with the general Ursicinus, who was active in Palestine in the year 351-2 (yBes1:7, 60c), see Introduction 7.4.3.
Judah (8), who was a student of Samuel (3), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.2.
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
His son cites traditions of the tanna, Eleazar (Eleazar [58] B/M in vol. 1, p. 66), see Introduction 7.4.1.

This person is only mentioned once (here) in the form ר' אלעזר ב"ר הושעיה. Elsewhere in PT we find the formula ר' אלעזר בשם ר' הושעיה (Rabbi Eleazar in the name of Rabbi Hoshaiah). Also Hyman does not record him. Yet in all the mss (Leiden, Vatican Paris, London) and in the Venice print here the first form is recorded. Only in the margins of the Leiden Ms is the text emended. I think this form is the lectio difficilior,but doubt lingers.
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

In Aramaic – דרומייה in yPeah 8:2, 20d and דרומיא in yYom6:6, 44a and yMeg1:8, 71b, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 212-4. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. In yGit6:7, 48b he is designated דמן רומא, which may imply that his provenance is the city of Rome, but this is doubtful. Although Hyman, Toldoth, 214 makes a distinction between the two, because he thinks they date from different times, but I think the same sage is intended, and the mistake is in the transmission tradition.

Hyman, Toldoth, 185, claims there is no such person, because in his appearance in yTer 11:2, 47d, the text which runs: לעזר ביה ר' ישמעאל should be read לעזר בשם ר' ישמעאל. However, he does not refer to the text here, which runs רבי ליעזר בן ישמעאל. This notwithstanding, because both texts refer beforehand to the tanna Rabbi Yishmael (Ishmael [4] B/M. in vol. 1, p. 177), he may be correct, and no such person exists.

An amora by the name of ר' אלעזר (Eleazar [8]) is mentioned often in PT (e.g. yBer 2:1, 4b) but never as the son of a פדת. Thus he appears only in BT, and I assume he is a different person. Hyman, Toldoth, 192, claims that Eleazar ben Pedat was Babylonian, but does not bring clear cut evidence for this. That he was the father of Pedat (1) S-H/M, mentioned often in PT, is shown in yMeg 4:10, 75c. Thus I assume he is Palestinian.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

Although he appears only here in BT, he is consistently designated by the title רבי and transmits a tradition in Hebrew, see above, n. 60. Hyman, Toldoth, 264 and 266 differentiates this ביבי בר אבינא and ביבי בר אבא but the mss tradition in Lev Rab 3:3 makes it clear that they are the same, see Margulies, Wiyyikra Rabbah, 61. Perhaps also mentioned in yTaan 2:4, 65d, as ביבי אבא.

In Coptic – ⲡⲁⲣⲭⲏⲉⲣⲉⲩⲥ. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4.
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
On this form see vol. 4, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 65.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 14. On this form see vol. 4, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 65.

person.note: His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 14. On this form see vol. 4, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 65.

person.note: Was a contemporary of Rabbi Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.
So also in PT, e.g. yTer9:1, 46c. For this form see above, n. 14. On this form see vol. 4, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 65.
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

So also in PT, e.g. yPes8:8, 36b. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see above, n. 14. On this form see vol. 4, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 65.
So also in PT, e.g. in ySot 6:4, 21a, see previous note. On this form see vol. 1, under Benjamin (4) B/M, p. 82. On the additional יs see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13.

So in BT, see above, n. 22. So also in PT, e.g. yPes8:8, 36b. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see above, n. 14. For this form see below, n. 27.
Not the same as the previous, see Hyman, Toldoth, 282, 303.
Was a student of Rav (in vol. 4, Abba [70] S-H/M, p. 311], who died in 247. On such dating see Introduction 7.4.5.

In vol. 4 I identified this form as a separate name (see under S-H/M, pp. 376-7), but because it is found only in BT (including this one), and because in Palestinian sources מנימין is often found as an alternative form to בנימין (see vol. 1, Benjamin [4], p. 82; vol. 3, Benjamin [1], p. 80; vol. 4, Benjamin [3, 4, 5], p, 65) and because in BT it is once found as an alternative reading to the name Benjamin (see vol. 4, under Benjamin [5] B/M, p. 65), I here assume that it is actually a variant of the same name.
Although he appears only here in BT, his son is consistently designated by the title רבי, see vol. 4, Introduction 7.1, pp. 39-40, and transmits a tradition in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5.
Naḥmani (1) B/M in vol. 4, p. 112 transmits in his son’s name. This is the date of his death.
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Aha (Ahi [1]), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see above, n. 2. On this form see vol 1, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 82.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
So is this name transliterated in Josephus, see Schalit, NB, 26.
On this form see vol 1, Benjamin (1), p. 82. The double ν is a standard Greek spelling variation, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.3, p. 11.

This is probably a Greek transliteration of the Hebrew form מניומי, see above, n. 27. In vol. 4 I identified this form as a separate name (see under S-H/M, pp. 376-7), but because it is found only in BT (including this one), and because in Palestinian sources מנימין is often found as an alternative form to בנימין (see vol. 1, Benjamin [4], p. 82; vol. 3, Benjamin [1], p. 80; vol. 4, Benjamin [3, 4, 5], p, 65) and because in BT it is once found as an alternative reading to the name Benjamin (see vol. 4, under Benjamin [5] B/M, p. 65), I here assume that it is actually a variant of the same name.
On the additional י as representing a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3.
In Aramaic – פרנסה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.1.
North of Jericho.

note.ref: See above, n. 32. The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
See above, n. 2. On this form see vol 1, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 82.

person.note: This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

See above, n. 41. This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
See above, n. 2. On this form see vol 1, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 82.

person.note: In Greek – ̔ προστάτης̔ Κεσαρεύς. On this title see vol. 3, under Yael (1) B/F, p. 179 and Introduction 3.1.3.4. On the geographical designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Jewishness suggested based on name, and provenance – Palestine – but see but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On this form see vol 1, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 82.

person.note: Rey-Coquais, Archéologie au Levant, 405, suggest identifying him with Benjamin (13) found in the cemetery at Jaffa (CIJ908). This identification is likely but not definite.
Located south of Beirut and north of Sidon.

The inscription is a dedicatory inscription to a building. It includes biblical names, but is late and thus could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. L. Roth Gerson, “A Greek Inscription at Khan Khalde,” Zion 56 (1991) 193-200 (Hebrew) identified it as a synagogue inscription. Her arguments, however, are not decisive. However the form ̓Ιωσῆ of the name of his brother is uniquely Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.2.3.
The inscription is dated to the era of the city of Beirut, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.
See above, n.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 32. The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

person.note: For this form see vol.1, under Besai (2) B/M, p. 84.
So in the Lerner edition. Either this is the name intended in which name בצלאל is a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18, or בוצלא is a scribal error.
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
These names are given as examples for signatures on a document, and probably do not represent real people.
His son is mentioned as giving his signature to a document mentioned by Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
In Transjordan.

For the form Βαροῦχος see vol. 1, under Baruch (1) B/M, p. 84. This form looks like a Greek transliteration of the form ברוכי. For such forms see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.2, p. 11. For this name see vol. 4, under Barachiah (2) B/M, pp. 66-7.
Transmits in the name of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.
So in the Munich Ms and in the Vilna print to bSot 49a and in the Jerusalem – Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms. to bSan 94b. On the additional י see under Hezekiah (6) B/M in vol. 1, pp. 95, and 96, n. 17.
Although he appears only in BT (here and in bSot49 and in bSan 94b), his son is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and transmits haggadic traditions, in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5-6.
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
In Aramaic – בוצרייה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 77-8. So only in Exod Rab10:1. In Gen Rab without place designation. On Bostra see Introduction 3.2.1.
His son transmits in the name of Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
In Aramaic – סבא. On this title see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.3, p. 33.
Abbin (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.
In Hebrew – הכהן ברבי. On the first title see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. On the second title see Introduction 3.1.1.
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
So in the parallel Tanḥuma (Warsaw edition). On this name see below under Zachariah B/M. This may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
See Introduction 5.1.4.2.
So according to Muntner, Assaph, 33-7.
For this form see vol. 3, under Barachiah (1) B/M, p. 81. The fall of the ι is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20.
The amulet comes from the region of Samaria and displays no Christian signs, but see Introduction 6.1.5.
The amulet is dated according to the Byzantine indictions, see Introduction 7.5.4.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 16. For this form see vol. 3, under Barachiah (1) B/M, p. 81. The fall of the ι is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20.

person.note: One person mentioned in this epitaph has a biblical name and the other a Semitic one, but in the period in which it was composed these could have been Christian names, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He is his contemporary.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 42.

Lehmann & Holum wrote about this inscription: “Because the names are biblical and he was able to restore a building dedication, Lifschitz assigned the donation ‘sans doute’ to a synagogue. But the names are found among Christians too.” I think that this study actually shows that they are found much more among Christians than among Jews.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
So in the parallel Tanḥuma(Warsaw edition) bahar 1. On this name see under S-H/M.
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source, but in association with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1.
See previous note.

All these versions appear in various mss, see Theodor-Albeck, Bereschit Rabba, 144. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4.
So in the printed text, see previous note. This is obviously a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. For this name see under Ami S-H/M.
Even if this is the said biblical name, it is very unlikely that it was used as a proper name, and see vol. 1, under Goliath (1) B/M, p. 84. On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
His son transmits in the name of Joshua (4), who was a student of Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
This is an exact transliteration into Latin from the Greek Γαμαλίηλος, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.2, p. 14. On this form in Greek see vol 1, under Gamaliel (1) B/M, p. 85.

Linder, JRIL, no. 41 is the document which removes this family from the status it held as patriarchs for the Jewish people for many generations, but the office he holds is designated in this document praefecturam. Marcellus, De Medicamentis 23,77 designates him patriarcha. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1.
According to M. Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen (Tübingen 1995) 331-2 this person could be identical with this or the next one.
This is the year the document was issued. According to Graetz, he should be dated to 400-25, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 206 and Introduction 7.4.6.

This is an exact transliteration into Latin from the Greek Γαμαλίηλ, short from Γαμαλίηλος, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.2, p. 14. It is the Greek spelling of this name in LXX, see H. & R. Suppl. 45.

This is a variant reading, see previous note. The additional h fits the transliteration of the name in the Vulgate in Num 1:10, which is also the product of Jerome. Which is the correction of which is hard to decide here.
In Latin - patriarcha. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1.
This is the year to which this letter of Jerome is dated. According to Graetz, he should be dated to 365-85, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 206 and Introduction 7.4.6.
Was a contemporary of Abba (8), who was a contemporary of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

Meaning after Rabban Gamaliel the 1st (of the New Testament, see vol. 1, under Gamaliel [1] B/M, p. 85) and Gamaliel the 2nd (of Yavneh, see vol. 1, under Gamaliel [4] B/M, p. 85). This one is Judah the Patriarch’s son, see vol. 1, under Judah (36) B/M, p. 113. On this family see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1.
According to Graetz, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 205 and Introduction 7.4.6.
In Aramaic – זוגא.
Was a late contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

Was a contemporary of Simon (3), who was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Mana (2), who was Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.
So in BS2:174. 3:9 has גמליאל. For the form Γαμαλίηλος see vol. 1, under Gamaliel (1) B/M, p. 85. On the fall of the Greek suffix see vol.3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.1, p. 11.
In Hebrew – רבי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. On such family names see vol. 4, Introduction 6.10.1, p. 39. However, in this case a tradition is cited in his name in a way that may indicate that this is the name of a rabbinic school, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.10.1, p. 39.

person.note: The inscription is accompanied by a cross, obviously implying Christianity. However, Di Segni, ibid., suggests, because of his sons’ names, that the father may have been a Jew or Samaritan, who converted to keep his job, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is dated according to the era of Gadara, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

This person is only mentioned once (here) in the form ר' אלעזר ב"ר הושעיה. Elsewhere in PT we find the formula ר' אלעזר בשם ר' הושעיה (Rabbi Eleazar in the name of Rabbi Hoshaiah). Also Hyman does not record him. Yet in all the mss (Leiden, Vatican, Paris, London) and in the Venice print here the first form is recorded. Only in the margins of the Leiden Ms is the text emended. I think this form is the lectio difficilior, but doubt lingers.
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
So he is designated in BT, e.g. bEruv 53a. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1.
Was of the earliest amoraim, see Introduction 7.4.1.
His father was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.
His son was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
For this form see vol. 4, under Hoshaiah (2) B/M, p. 68.
Was a contemporary of Judah (10) the Patriarch, who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

So in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400), the Oxford Opp. Add. Fol. 23 and in the Munich 140 Mss. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see above, n. 8. For this form see vol. 4, under Hoshaiah (2) B/M, p. 68.
So in the Goettingen 3, the Cambridge T-S F2 (2) 73 and the Munich 95 Mss, see previous note. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26.

So in the Vatican 487 Ms, see above, n. 10. So in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400), the Oxford Opp. Add. Fol. 23 and in the Munich 140 Mss. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. Although mentioned only here in BT, he reacts to the words of Palestinian sages (see Introduction 5.3.2.3) and in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5.

So in bSan 25a. For this form see vol. 4, under Hoshaiah (2) B/M, p. 68.

Tanḥum (3), who transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), also transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

person.note: This could be this name with a letter reversal (see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20). However, Naveh, OSM, 124 does not think this is a name, but part of a prayer, with the word “save us.”
Village in southern Mount Hebron.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

The reading is mine. The editors had other suggestions. For this form see vol. 1, under Joseph (16) B/M, p. 150. There it is the alternative reading of the name and obviously this is the name intended, Joseph being a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.
In the Golan.

In this text he is described as being nominated εἰς πατριαρχίαν (to the patriarchate). On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1.
Epiphanius informs us that on his deathbed he summoned the bishop and ̔ πατριάρχης τοῦ λουτροῦ καταξιοῦται καὶ μαρτυρίων ἁγιων (the patriarch was granted baptism and the holy mysteries).

Was a contemporary of the Emperor Constantine. These are his dates. According to Graetz, he should be dated to 320-65, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 205 and Introduction 7.4.6.
His father/in/law was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

Was a late contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. On this sort of kern form see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He was his contemporary.

So in yBer1:5, 3d. In yShebi 1:5, 33b זבדי. For the form זבדא see vol. 4, under Zebediah (8) B/M, p. 69.
His son was a contemporary of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

Usual form זבדי but so in yBer2:8, 5c. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it. Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

So in the Vatican, Paris and London Mss of yBer 1:5, 3b as well as the Vatican and London Mss to yBer 6:5, 6c. On this name see below. This may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.

This figure could be a literary invention, since the text runs: ר' טוביה בר' יצחק אמר: שני אהלים רות המואביה ונעמה העמונית. דכוותה "קום קח את אשתך ואת שתי בנותיך הנמצאות" (בראשית יט טו). ר' טוביה אמר: שתי מציאות רות ונעמה. אמר ר' יצחק: "מצאתי דוד עבדי" (תהלים פט כא). איכו מצאתיו? בסדום. “Rabbi Tobiah son of Rabbi Isaac said: Two tents – Ruth the Moabite and Naama the Amonite. And likewise: “Arise and take your two daughters found here” (Gen 19:15). Rabbi Tobiah said: Two found – Ruth and Naama. Rabbi Isaac said: “I have found my slave David” (Ps 89:21). Where have I found him? In Sodom.” Since in the the introductory passage there are two names mentioned as father and son, and further down two rabbis by these same two names are mentioned, perhaps there really was no such sage with a combined name, and this is merely a literary combination.

The text tells of Abdimi (1) (S-H/M - vol. 4, p. 318) coming to Babylonia and transmitting a tradition in his name and in the name of Simon (32). Usually ר' יהודה ור' שמעון are the famous Judah (30) B/M vol.1, p. 113 and Simon (51) B/M vol. 1, p. 220, but they cannot be students of Yohanan (1). Thus I assume these are otherwise unknown students, from Palestine of course, although it cannot be ruled out that they are a literary invention of an early sage.

The text is as follows: רבי יצחק בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי צומא רבא. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה: איסתניס אני. רבי יהושע בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי תעניתה. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה איסתניס אני (Rabbi Isaac bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of the Great Fast [i.e. Yom Kippur] He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive. Rabbi Joshua bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of fasting. He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive).. Perhaps the second is simply a literary parallel and not a historical figure.
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

person.note: In Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 430-1 one is informed that any Joseph son of Joshua refers to Joseph (34) son of Joshua ben Levi (vol. 1, Joshua [25], p. 126) but the text here does not imply this. Hyman, Toldoth, 728 identified him as a separate person, also mentioned in bHul 56b and bNid 24a, but because he is cited by Rabbi Yohanan (1), he thinks he was a tanna, i.e. too early for this volume. Yet he is only recorded in amoraic literature.
Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

He is mentioned by Isaac (4), who transmitted traditions in the name of late tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

In this chronicle, just before he is mentioned, we are informed that 166 years after the destruction of the Temple there was a war between Rome and the Persians. He was therefore supposed to have lived shortly thereafter.
In this composition Se‘adya Gaon explains the work of poets (אלשערא in Judeo-Arabic), and lists this one among them, see Introduction 3.1.3.6.
Zulay, Eretz Israel, 165 dates him to the Byzantine period, see Introduction 7.5.5.

The name אישו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 75 and the form ’ŠW is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 50).

This is an inn inscription. It bears Hebrew names and a biblical quotation (1 Sam 16:4). Yet its tentative date (and the popularity of this name among Christians, see vol. 3, Introduction 1.1.1.2, p. 4-5) puts its Jewish character into question, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. IJO 3, App19 specifically denied the Jewishness of this inscription.

state.note: Inscription on column base, Sheikh Meyser

person.note: This is all that could be read from the publication. Perhaps another name is intended and maybe other names were found on this inscription. If this is the name intended the following observations can be made: On the interchange of ω and ο, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. On the form ̓Ιοάνη, see vol. 3, under Yohanan (23) B/M, p. 106. The additional ε is obviously a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.1, p. 20. The declension is probably in the vocative.

The inscription mentions εἱς Θεός ἁ πάντων Δεσπότης (one God who rules all) but this is no indication of Jewishness, especially not in Zoar, see Introduction 6.1.6. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.

Macarius could also be considered this Yohanan’s son, but the way the inscription is transcribed (Κύρω Μεγάλου̔ίου τοὺ Μακαρίου ̓Ιωανάνου) suggests that it should be translated for Cyrus, [son of] Megalus, son of Macarius Yohanan. The editor translated Μακαρίου as “the blessed” (המאושר), but such an interpretation is unnecessary.

This is the only location where this sage appears, but he is associated with the Palestinian Rabbi Abbahu (1), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3, and the title רב (see vol. 4, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 36) is absent from the best mss, indicating that it is late. He is probably also mentioned in the Vatican 487 Ms to bShab 116a.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

The initial editor suggested that this is the biblical name ישי, King David’s father, but there is no indication that the name was transcribed so in LXX or other Greek renditions of the Bible. Roth-Gerson, GISEI, p. 92, suggested that it is a Greek rendition of the variant איסי (see above, Joseph [23]). This is quite a straightforward transliteration, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1, p. 11. On the interchange of ιwith η as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21.

person.note: The name is written in reverse order here. For this phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.7.6, p. 31.

The inscription (on a marble plaque) is not typical of Second Temple Jerusalem, and at later times it is hardly likely to find Jewish tombs in Jerusalem. The inscription bears the marks of a late-antique Jewish epitaph similar to those found for example in Jaffa. How it made its way to Jerusallem’s rubbish heaps is unclear. Thus, some scholars assume it is medieval (as in CIIP 1/2, no. 881**).

South of Beirut and north of Sidon.

The inscription is a dedicatory inscription to a building. It includes biblical names, but is late and thus could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. L. Roth Gerson, “A Greek Inscription at Khan Khalde,” Zion 56 (1991) 193-200 (Hebrew) identified it as a synagogue inscription. Her arguments, however, are not decisive. In this case Jewishness is indicated by the form of the name, see Introduction 6.2.2.3.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the City of Beirut, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4.

person.note: In the inscription his death is described as follows: דגז בטפר מדינתה בארעהון דחמיראי ונפק לארעה דישראל ואקבר (who died in the City of Tafar in the Land of the Hamyarites and went forth to the Land of Israel and was buried). From this it is not clear whether he was a native of Palestine who was away and died abroad, or whether he was a Native of Himyar (Yemen) and was then buried in what was for him the Holy Land.
The inscription is dated to 400 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

In Syriac – ܒܗܢܐ ܙܒܢܐ ܡܬܝܕܥ (at the time [he] became known). These words are followed by a list of Christian officials such as Athanasius the patriarch of Antioch. But this Jacob has no such title, and instead he is designated ܝܗܘܕܝܐ (=Jew). Editors thought this is probably a mistake and refers to Jacob of Edessa, see Chronicon Anonymum Pseudo-Dionysianum (translation into French – Robert Hespel; Corpus Scriptorum Christianorum Orientalium 507; Scriptores Syrie 213), Louvan 1989, 111, n. 1 and Chabot, ibid.

He is mentioned in four traditions. In three of them, two of them Palestinian and one Babylonian (yShevi 9:4, 39a; ySheq 4:2, 48a; bKet 106a) he is designated with the Palestinian title רבי and is found in association with Palestinian rabbis. In another Babylonian tradition (bShab 23b) he bears the Babylonian title רב and transmits a tradition in the name of a Babylonian rabbi (רב הונא – Huna [1] S-H/M in vol. 4, p. 347). However, the earlier Palestinian traditions seem more reliable, and contra Hyman, Toldoth, 798.

Appears only in BT, here and in bHul 27b (and also in bQid71a, but not in the Vilna print, where his name has been skipped), but I assume he is Palestinian because he is always designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, because in bPes 114a he is designated דאגדתא (he who transmits aggadah, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.6) and in bQid 71 he is described within the context of the Palestinian study house. Hyman, Toldoth, 782-4 argues that he is the person designated simply Isaac (5) in PT, but he has no proof for this, and Isaac (5) is probably Ahi (7)’s son.

This figure could be a literary invention, since the text runs: ר' טוביה בר' יצחק אמר: שני אהלים רות המואביה ונעמה העמונית. דכוותה "קום קח את אשתך ואת שתי בנותיך הנמצאות" (בראשית יט טו). ר' טוביה אמר: שתי מציאות רות ונעמה. אמר ר' יצחק: "מצאתי דוד עבדי" (תהלים פט כא). איכו מצאתיו? בסדום. “Rabbi Tobiah son of Rabbi Isaac said: Two tents – Ruth the Moabite and Naama the Amonite. And likewise: “Arise and take your two daughters found here” (Gen 19:15). Rabbi Tobiah said: Two found – Ruth and Naama. Rabbi Isaac said: “I have found my slave David” (Ps 89:21). Where have I found him? In Sodom.” Since in the the introductory passage there are two names mentioned as father and son, and further down two rabbis by these same two names are mentioned, perhaps there really was no such sage with a combined name, and this is merely a literary combination.

This is a long story. At the beginning רבי זעירא (Ze‘ira [4]) and a certain ר' ירמיה are seated together. This could be Jeremiah (2). In the end of the episode we read אמר רבי זעירה ... ירמיה בני (Said Rabbi Ze‘ira: … Jeremiah my son …). This could be interpreted as a condescending epithet, but it could imply a real family relationship, in which case this is another Jeremiah.

However, he does not refer to the text here, which runs רבי ליעזר בן ישמעאל. Nevertheless, because both texts refer beforehand to the tanna Rabbi Yishmael (Ishmael [4] B/M. in vol. 1, p. 177), he may be correct, and no such person exists.

The consonants in this name are the same, but the vowels are completely different from those in other forms of the name here. With these vowels the name would be pronounced like the name of the despised biblical idol Molech (e.g. Jer 32:35). If this is indeed the name intended here, this makes the likelyhood that he is Jewish smaller.

Ben Zvi maintained that it is impossible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4.

person.note: The text is as follows: רבי יצחק בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי צומא רבא. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה: איסתניס אני. רבי יהושע בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי תעניתה. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה איסתניס אני (Rabbi Isaac bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of the Great Fast [i.e. Yom Kippur] He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive. Rabbi Joshua bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of fasting. He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive). Perhaps the second is simply a literary parallel and not a historical figure.
His son was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

In bKet 105b a tradition by him is transmitted in Babylonia by a נחותי (i.e. a sage who transmits Palestinian traditions in Babylonia, and see Hyman, Toldoth, 945) , and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.4.

person.note: So in the parallel in yBer 3:2, 6b. Where he is designated שמעון דתוספתא, in the Leiden, Paris and London Mss. In the Vatican Ms. שמוא' דתוספתה. It is hard to decide which is the correct reading.

In Aramaic – דסופפתא. I do not know where this place is. Reeg, Ortsnamen, does not mention it. If the correct reading is תוספתה (see previous note) than he is not from Palestine at all, but rather from Ctesiphon in Mesopotamia, see Oppenheimer, Babylonia Judaica , 206-7. But סופפתא is the lectio difficilior, and he is mentioned only in PT.

The suggestion that this is a Jewish inscription is based, 1. On the formula Εἱς Θεός (God is one), but see Introduction 6.1.6; 2. However, the name of his brother, Tanḥum, was clearly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.2.4.

The inscription was found in Tiberias, a mainly Jewish city. It may be assumed that Antiocheans with biblical names, who migrated from Syria to Tiberias in Palestine were Jews, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1. However, IJO 3, App18 specifically denied the Jewishness of this inscription.

It is not clear in which alphabet the name appears. Negev reports about it in this early popular publication but not in his final report (see next note). It may have been in Greek or in Nabatean. I present it here in Hebrew because Negev’s publication is in this language, see Introduction 2.4.

In this popular book in Hebrew, Negev writes: “Samuel, the artist who produced this fresco, signed his name under one of his paintings” (translation and paraphrase mine). Nowhere (not even in his book Greek Inscriptions from the Negev (Jerusalem 1981), where he published all other inscriptions from Mampsis, and mentioned the exact fresco he claims this Samuel has painted, has he published this inscription.
In the Negev.

According to J. Goodman, “The Frescoes in Building XII,” in A. Negev (ed.), The Architecture of Mampsis, Final Report. Vol I: The Middle and Late Nabatean Period (Qedem 26; Jerusalem 1988) 147, the frescoes are no older than 222 and thus are unlikely to be Christian. The name is, therefore, Jewish and so must the artist have been.
See previous note.

The text tells of Abdimi (1) (S-H/M in vol. 4, 318) coming to Babylonia and transmitting a tradition in his and Judah (47)’s name. Usually ר' יהודה ור' שמעון are the famous Judah (30) B/M vol.1, p. 113 and Simon (51) B/M vol. 1, p. 220, but they cannot be students of Yohanan (1). Thus I assume these are otherwise unknown students, from Palestine of course, although it cannot be ruled out that they are a literary invention of an early sage.

In Aramaic – תפילות וסילחות שמסרו לנו רבותינו אנשי השם מימות שמעון כיפה שיסד סדר של יום הכיפורים (prayers and forgiveness-beggings that were handed down to us by our renown teachers from the days of Shimeon Kefa, who founded the ritual for the Day of Atonement). Who this Shimeon Kefa was is unclear, as perhaps the other reference to him in Mahzor Vitri demonstrates. In §66 someone who is also reputed to have written liturgical poetry (נשמת כל חי) is designated אותו נבל שמעון פטר חמור (that criminal Shimeon Peter [=also in Hebrew firstborn] of a donkey) and in Krauss, Leben Jesu, pp. 86-8, he is identified as Simon Peter (in vol. 1, Simon [35] B/M. p. 219), although his role as liturgical poet is maintained (עשה הרבה פזמונים גדולים לישראל וכולם קימים בשמו). I agree with H. Graetz, “Die Anfänge der neuhebräischen Poesie,” Monatsschrift für Geschichte und Wissenschaft des Judentums 9 (1860) 21-2 that “Simon Kephas ist aber keine Mythe, sondern der Name eine jüdischen Poetan.”

Although Graetz (see previous note) identifies him as a contemporary of the earliest paytanim, his name only shows up in medieval compositions. Thus we do not really know when to date him, and if he belongs to antiquity at all.

The inscription is bilingual Greek and Latin. So in the Latin. In the Vulgate the reading is for Gen 25:15 is Thema. This is a close enough rendition.

In Greek – Κανωθαι[́ω]ν ἐπ[ὶ]Συρίης. In Latin – Septimiano Canotha (Septimiana being the Latin name of the town). Canatha is situated in Transjordan. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

Oehler, MGWJ53 (1909) 449 writes “vielleicht ein Jude” probably based on the fact that he came to Gaul from Syria and had a Semitic name, but both criteria are not decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. CIJ thought he was a pagan.
The name of the town “[S]eptimiano,” is after the emperor Septimius Severus. This is the year in which he died, see Introduction 7.1.

The inscriptions are bilingual, Greek and Palmyran. This is the Greek (BS 2:11, 12). It is very different from the Greek renditions of this name in LXX, but the Palmyran version makes the idenitification with this name certain.

The inscriptions are bilingual Greek and Palmyran. This is the Palmyran (BS1:12), see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 19. On biblical names losing their vocalization see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13.
In Greek – τῶν ̓Αμαση. In Hebrew – אמשא. This is in Syria. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

div.note: Biblical, see e.g. Num 1:11.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 14:1. אביה was the name of an Israelite prince. It is also the name of a biblical priestly course: 1 Chr 24:10.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 22:20. אביתר was a priest under King David.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:5. אברהם is the name of the famous biblical patriarch, forefather of the Jewish people.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 3:3. אבשלום was David’s rebellious son.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 4:14. אהרון was the name of Moses’ brother, the first priest.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:21. The word אחא means brother in Aramaic.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 11:29. אחיה was a prophet.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 17:1. אליהו was the name of a prophet.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:4.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 23:20. אליקים was a king of Judah.
Biblical priestly course: 1 Chr 24:12.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. אלישע was a prophet, and Elijah’s disciple.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. 1Sam 1:1. אלקנה was the name of the prophet Samuel’s father.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:41.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 48:5. אפרים was Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:13. אשר was one of the twelve sons of Jacob.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:11. The name is probably Aramaic, since it is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 111.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 11:22. בניה is one of King David’s generals.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 35:18. בנימין is Jacob’s youngest son and one of the tribes of Israel.

Biblical, e.g. Neh 7:52. The name is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). It is also documented on Hebrew First Temple seals (CWSSSnos. 110, 424). בסא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 77).
Biblical, e.g. Exod 31:2.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:12. ברוך was Jeremiah’s scribe.
Biblical, e.g. Zach 1:1.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 4:8. ברק was the Prophetess Deborah’s partner.
Biblical, e.g. Dan 18:6. גבריאל is the name of an archangel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:5. גדליה was the Judaean prefect nominated by the Babylonians after destruction of the First Temple.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 17:4. גלית was the name of the Philistine giant David overcame in battle.
Biblical, e.g. Num 1:10.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 2:22. גרשום was one of Moses’ sons.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 16:13. דוד was the name of the famous king of Israel.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:18.
Biblical, e.g. Dan 1:7. דניאל is the biblical figure who gave his name to the Book of Daniel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 42:1.

Biblical, e.g. Judg 12:13. In the case of Hillel, the relative popularity of the name in the latter documents found in this list may be the result of the popularity of Hillel the Elder and his activities in Palestine.

Biblical, Josh 7:1. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 85-6; and in Idumea, see AOFCI, 99.
Biblical, 1 Chr 8:17. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews.
Biblical, 1 Chr 2:33.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 1:1. זכריה is the prophet who gave the name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Hagai 1:12. חגי was the post-exilic prophet who gave the name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:1. חזקיה was king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1. חכליה was Nehemiah’s father.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:37.
Biblical, e.g. Num 34:23.

Biblical, e.g. Jer 35:4. This name has such an independent standing that one often loses sight of the fact that it is probably an abbreviation of חנניה. Because this distinction is already biblical, I have not listed the two names under a single heading here.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 28:1.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10.
Biblical, e.g. Num 32:41.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The longer form – יאשיהו – is the name of a king of Judah (2 Kgs 21:26).
Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:22.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:35. יהודה was one of Jacob’s sons, and a tribe of Israel. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2. Further on this name see Introduction 6.2.2.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Chr 17:18.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 17:9. יהושע was the name of the general, Moses’ successor, who gave his name to a biblical book. On the Jewishness of this name in a post-Chriatian era see Introduction 6.2.2.1.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:16. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2. Further on this name and its use by Jews see Introduction 6.2.2.2.
Biblical, 2 Kgs 14:25. יונה was the prophet after whom a biblical book is called.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 13:2. Jonathan was King Saul’s son. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:24. יוסף was a son of Jacob. On the suggestion that it was also a name of a Hasmonean brother, see vol. 1, under Joseph B/M, p. 158, n. 20.
Biblical, 1 Chr 12:7.
Biblical, e.g. 1Chr 2:55.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:26. יעקב is the third Patriarch. On this name see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 5:32. יפת was one of Noah’s three sons.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:19. יצחק is the second Patriarch, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 8:19.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 27:1. ירמיה was the prophet who gave his name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 16:11. ישמעאל was Abraham’s first-born, rejected son see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1, pp. 5-6.
Biblical, e.g. Ezr 8:7. ישעיהו was the prophet who gave his name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 32:29. ישראל is the second name given by God to Jacob.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:18. יששכר was a son of Jacob, and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 4:18. יתרו was the name of Moses’ father-in-law.
Biblical, e.g. Num 13:6. כלב was one of the spies Moses sent to inspect Canaan.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:34. לוי was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, Jer 32:12.
Biblical, 1 Chr 8:9.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 50:23.

Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 9:12. In vol. 1, (מלכה) S-H/M, pp. 390-1 and in vol. 3 (מלכא) S-H/M, pp. 674-7, I recorded variants of this name under Other (mostly Semitic) Names in the Hebrew Alphabet, because the biblical form of the name never showed up. In this volume, as in vol. 4, it shows up once, so I recorded the name under biblical names.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:14. מנחם was the one before last king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 41:51. מנשה is Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 12:5.
Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:1. מרדכי was Queen Esther’s uncle.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 2:10. משה was the great leader of the Exodus.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:3.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 24:17.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:43. This name is only documented In post-exilic biblical books (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. נדב was the name of a King of Israel, see 1 Kgs 14:20.
Biblical, e.g. Nah 1:1. נחום was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book. According to Noth, IPRGN, 38,
Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1. נחמיה was the Jewish leader who gave his name to a historical biblical book.
Biblical, Neh 7:7.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. נחשון was the nasi of the tribe of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:8. נפתלי was one of Jacob’s twelve sons and a tribe of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:12. נריה was the name of Baruch, Jeremiah’s scribe’s father.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 7:2. נתן was the name of David’s prophet.
Biblical, e.g. Num 1:8.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 6:29.
Biblical e.g. Ruth 4:17.
In the Bible the name is documented as עזיאל, e.g. Exod 6:22.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:4.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 3:19.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:1. עזרא is the scribe who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:21. עזריה was a king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:3. עלי was the priest who brought up Samuel.
Biblical, e.g. Amos 1:1. עמוס is the name of the prophet who gave the book the name.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:18. עמרם was Moses’ father.
Biblical, Neh 10:27.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:45.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 23:36.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:23.
Biblical, 1 Chr 3:24.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס.
Biblical, Num 34:25. This is most likely a Persian name (Φαρνάκης – Pharnak, see, Justi, INB, 92-3).
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:23.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 15:24. צדוק was King David’s priest.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:32. ראובן was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 9:2. שאול was the first king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:3. שבא was one of Abraham’s descendants from Qetura.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 20:1.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:15.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:13. שלום was the name of a king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 12:24. שלמה was the son of David, King of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 37:3.
Biblical, e.g. Hos. 10:4.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:20. שמואל was the prophet who gave his name to two biblical books.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:33. שמעון was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. Note also, that this is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 12:22.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. Shafat was the name of the prophet Elisha’s father.
Biblical, 1 Chr 4:12.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:15. The name is associated with a son of Ishmael – i.e. it may be of Arab extraction. The name תימא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 117).
